page.title: 05Conservation
page.content: Many feel that the precious chalk downland - a National Heritage Area - on which many rare flowers such as cowslips, kidney vetch, fragrant and bee orchids, viper's bugloss and field fleawort grow, should be conserved by reclaiming the land from farmers and their crops. However, this would entail great expenditure as the land would have to be kept free from scrub by tractors rather than by sheep grazing as it is now. Never the less, the farmers in the area, unlike most others, are prohibited by law to use pesticides as the downland is a water-catchment area. Perhaps it is the great public dislike of barbed-wire fences and corrugated-iron sheds that disfigure the landscape that strengthens the case of those opposed to farming on the Downs.
